artefact.overview: Permit to carry out Part A(2) or Part B activities or run a Part A(2) or Part B installation or mobile plant.
artefact.licence_short_description: Permit to carry out Part A(2) or Part B activities or run a Part A(2) or Part B installation or mobile plant.
artefact.licence_overview:
You must hold an environmental permit from your local authority if you either:

- carry out Part A(2) or Part B activities
- run a Part A(2) or Part B installation or mobile plant

Activities which require a Part A(2) permit include:

- refining gas
- metal works - eg producing pig iron or steel, casting ferrous metal, operating forge hammers or applying fused metal coatings
- melting non-ferrous metals
- surface treating metals and plastic materials
- grinding cement clinker or metallurgical slag
- glass manufacturing
- cellulose fibre reinforced calcium silicate board manufacturing
- ceramic product manufacturing - including roof tiles and bricks
- non-hazardous or animal waste incineration
- manufacturing wood based boards - eg plywood
- new tyre manufacturing
- disposing of or recycling animal carcases or waste

Activities which require a Part B permit are those which cause emissions to air.

However, not all activities which fall within those categories will require a Part A(2) or B permit. Waste operations that cause more significant pollution will instead require a Part A(1) permit from the [Environment Agency.](http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk "Environment Agency"){:rel="external"}  If you carry out an exempt waste operation, an exempt water discharge activity or an exempt groundwater activity, you may need to register the activity as an exempt operation with either the Environment Agency or your local authority.

You may be charged a fee when you apply for a Part A(2) or B environmental permit.

If your local authority believes that you have breached a permit condition, or are likely to breach a condition, you may be served with an enforcement notice. This will detail the suspected breaches, the steps that you must take to remedy them and the time period you have to take such steps.

If they believe that your regulated facility is causing, or is likely to cause serious pollution, they may serve you with a suspension notice, suspending your permit.

##Fines and penalties

If you fail to provide information when requested, provide false or misleading information, make a false entry in any records you keep or forge or use a forged document or permit, you may be committing a criminal offence and may be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both. If you fail to provide information requested in relation to your application, the application may be withdrawn.

If the court believes you have the power to remedy your contravention, you may be ordered to take specified steps for remedying the matter, in addition to or instead of a fine or imprisonment.

If the local authority takes action to prevent pollution or remedy any pollution that has occurred as a result of your actions, they may seek to recover the costs of doing so from you.

If you fail to comply with the requirement to hold an environmental permit, you may be fined, imprisoned for up to five years or both.
